passage:
(1) Nanotechnology, the manipulation of matter at the molecular and atomic scale, is revolutionizing modern medicine by enabling unprecedented precision in treatment and diagnosis. Medical researchers are developing nanoscale devices, typically between 1 and 100 nanometers in size, that can interact with cells and tissues at their most basic levels. These tiny innovations are small enough to enter most cells, travel through the bloodstream, and even cross the blood-brain barrier—a significant advantage over traditional medical approaches that often rely on systemic delivery methods.

(2) One of the most promising applications of nanotechnology in medicine is targeted drug delivery. Conventional drug administration methods distribute medication throughout the entire body, often resulting in side effects when healthy tissues are affected. In contrast, nanoparticles can be engineered to deliver medications directly to diseased cells, leaving healthy cells untouched. These nanocarriers can be designed with specific surface properties that allow them to recognize and bind only to particular cell types, such as cancer cells, thereby increasing therapeutic efficacy while minimizing adverse reactions.

(3) Diagnostic capabilities are similarly being transformed through nanoscale innovations. Quantum dots—tiny semiconductor particles that emit light of specific wavelengths when exposed to light—are enabling more sensitive and detailed imaging of biological processes. Additionally, nanobiosensors can detect disease markers at much lower concentrations than traditional diagnostic methods, potentially allowing for earlier disease detection. These advances could lead to more accurate diagnoses and treatment monitoring, particularly for complex conditions like cancer and neurodegenerative diseases.

(4) Despite these promising developments, the integration of nanotechnology into mainstream medicine faces several challenges. Safety concerns regarding the potential toxicity of certain nanomaterials must be thoroughly addressed through rigorous testing. Regulatory frameworks need to evolve to appropriately evaluate these novel technologies. Moreover, the manufacturing processes required to produce medical nanodevices at scale remain complex and expensive, creating barriers to widespread adoption and accessibility.

(5) Nevertheless, the future of nanomedicine appears bright as researchers continue to overcome these obstacles. Personalized medicine, where treatments are tailored to individual genetic profiles, may become more feasible through nanotechnology. The field is also exploring theranostic applications—devices that combine therapeutic and diagnostic functions, allowing for real-time monitoring of treatment efficacy. As these technologies mature, they promise to fundamentally change our approach to healthcare, potentially offering more effective, less invasive, and more personalized medical interventions.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly uses the present perfect tense?

options.A: She have been studying for the exam since morning.
options.B: They have lived in this neighborhood for ten years.
options.C: I has been working on this project for three weeks.
options.D: He had not finished the assignment yet.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with the correct subject-verb agreement.

options.A: The group of students were discussing the assignment.
options.B: Each of the participants have submitted their forms.
options.C: Neither the teacher nor the students were informed.
options.D: The data shows significant improvements in all areas.

questions.question: Identify the correct passive voice construction.

options.A: They builded the new library last year.
options.B: The document had been signed by the manager yesterday.
options.C: The computer was been fixing by the technician.
options.D: The exhibition will be opened by the mayor next week.

questions.question: Which sentence contains a correctly used relative clause?

options.A: The woman which I met yesterday is a famous scientist.
options.B: The book that I borrowed it from the library was very interesting.
options.C: The restaurant where we had dinner last night has excellent reviews.
options.D: The students who had been failed the exam must retake it next week.

questions.question: Select the grammatically correct sentence referring to a past situation.

options.A: If I would have known the truth, I would have told you.
options.B: If I had known the truth, I would have told you.
options.C: If I knew the truth, I would have told you.
options.D: Had I know the truth, I would have told you.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the modal verb correctly?

options.A: You must to arrive by 9 AM tomorrow.
options.B: She can singing very well.
options.C: They might not be able to attend the class.
options.D: He should to calling his parents more often.

questions.question: Identify the sentence with the correct use of articles.

options.A: She is the better student in the class.
options.B: He bought a umbrella because it was raining.
options.C: They visited famous museum in Paris last summer.
options.D: We had an interesting discussion about the global economy.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with the correct use of comparatives and superlatives.

options.A: That was the most interesting lecture I've ever attended.
options.B: Her presentation was way more better than his.
options.C: This is the most easiest exercise in the book.
options.D: This hotel is much more cheaper than the one downtown.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the gerund correctly?

options.A: She enjoys to swim in the warm ocean.
options.B: They admitted stealing the documents.
options.C: I look forward to seeing your soon.
options.D: He suggested to go to the museum.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct use of reported speech.

options.A: She said me that she was tired.
options.B: He told that he would finish the project soon.
options.C: They asked when did the meeting start.
options.D: The teacher said that the test would be difficult.

questions.question: Which sentence demonstrates the correct use of future perfect tense?

options.A: By next year, they will completed the construction.
options.B: She will have finished her degree by the end of this semester.
options.C: We will been working on this project for two years in December.
options.D: He will has traveled to twenty countries by his thirtieth birthday.

questions.question: Identify the sentence with correct preposition usage.

options.A: She arrived to the airport at time for her flight.
options.B: We are looking forward for the summer vacation.
options.C: He has been working at this company since 2015.
options.D: They were waiting the bus for over an hour.

questions.question: Choose the sentence with the correct use of the past perfect tense.

options.A: After I had finished my homework, I watched YT.
options.B: Before she arrived, we have already left the party.
options.C: He had been lived in Paris before moving to London.
options.D: They had went to the store before cooking dinner.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the infinitive correctly?

options.A: She wants to learning a new language.
options.B: They decided buying a new car next year.
options.C: He helped me to carry the heavy boxes upstairs.
options.D: I expect to finishing the project by next Friday.

questions.question: Select the sentence with correct subject-verb inversion.

options.A: Never I have seen such a beautiful sunset.
options.B: Rarely does she complain about her workload.
options.C: Not only he speaks English but also French.
options.D: Hardly they could believe the news.

questions.question: Complete the sentence: 'The government has the ________ to make decisions about national security.'

options.A: authority
options.B: authorization
options.C: authorized
options.D: authorize

options.A: Lasting for a very long time
options.B: Lasting for only a limited period of time
options.C: Of high quality or standard
options.D: Happening regularly over a period of time

options.C: His political disasters banned him from being elected this year.
options.D: Their understanding of the importance of education was a disaster.

options.A: He is very responsible of his younger siblings.
options.B: She's responsible on creating the marketing strategy.
options.C: They were held responsible for the data breach.
options.D: I'm responsible by making sure everyone is safe.

options.D: He prefers stay at home on cold days.

options.A: Coming after something in time or order
options.B: Existing or occurring before something else
options.C: Happening at the same time as something else
options.D: Likely to happen in the distant past or future

questions.question: According to paragraph 1, what makes nanotechnology particularly valuable in medicine?

options.A: Its ability to manipulate existing matter at the molecular level
options.B: Its ability to cross barriers that traditional medications cannot
options.C: Its low production cost compared to traditional treatments
options.D: Its widespread availability in healthcare systems in recent years

questions.question: The primary advantage of nanoparticles in drug delivery, as mentioned in paragraph 2, is that they:

options.A: Are less expensive and faster to produce than conventional drugs
options.B: Can deliver higher doses of medication with fewer side effects
options.C: Can target specific cells while leaving healthy cells untouched
options.D: Can completely eliminate the need for traditional medications

questions.question: Which of the following is a diagnostic application of nanotechnology mentioned in the passage?

options.A: Replacing surgical procedures
options.B: Creating artificial organs
options.C: Monitoring patients remotely
options.D: Quantum dots for more sensitive imaging

questions.question: According to paragraph 4, which of the following is NOT a challenge facing nanomedicine?

options.A: Potential toxicity of nanomaterials
options.B: Lack of patient acceptance
options.C: Complex and expensive manufacturing processes
options.D: Inadequate regulatory frameworks

questions.question: What does the author suggest about the future of nanomedicine in paragraph 5?

options.A: It will completely replace traditional medicine within a decade
options.B: It will make healthcare more personalized and less invasive
options.C: It will focus exclusively on cancer treatments
options.D: It will primarily benefit wealthy countries

questions.question: The term 'theranostic' in paragraph 5 refers to devices that:

options.A: Combine therapeutic and diagnostic functions
options.B: Replace damaged tissues with artificial ones
options.C: Monitor patient vital signs remotely
options.D: Match treatments to genetic profiles

questions.question: What can be inferred about the current state of nanomedicine from the passage?

options.A: It is widely used in hospitals around the world
options.B: It is mainly theoretical with few practical applications
options.C: It shows great promise but faces implementation challenges
options.D: It has been largely abandoned recently due to safety concerns

questions.question: The passage suggests that nanobiosensors offer an advantage over traditional diagnostic methods because they:

options.A: Are more affordable for healthcare systems
options.B: Provide immediate results without processing
options.C: Eliminate the constant need for laboratory testing
options.D: Can detect disease markers at lower concentrations

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the author's tone in this passage?

options.A: Highly skeptical of nanotechnology's benefits
options.B: Cautiously optimistic about nanomedicine's potential
options.C: Overly enthusiastic without acknowledging limitations
options.D: Neutral and disinterested in the topic

questions.question: What is the main purpose of this passage?

options.A: To provide an overview of nanotechnology applications in medicine
options.B: To warn about the dangers of nanotechnology applications in medicine
options.C: To argue that funding for nanomedicine should be increased
options.D: To compare nanomedicine with traditional medical approaches
